Regularization penalties in owl

Johan Larsson

2019-12-18

Source: vignettes/penalties.Rmd
penalties.Rmd

Sorted L-One Penalized Estimation (SLOPE)

The SLOPE penalty attempts to control the false discovery rate (FDR) of non-zero coefficients (feature weights) in the model. It is in many ways analogous to the Benjamini–Hochberg procedure for multiple comparisons.

Let’s set up a simple experiment to see how SLOPE controls the FDR.

library(owl)
library(lattice)

# proportion of real signals
q <- seq(0.05, 0.5, length.out = 20)
fdr <- double(length(q))
set.seed(1)

for (i in seq_along(q)) {
  n <- 1000
  p <- n/2
  sigma <- 1
  problem <- owl:::randomProblem(n, p, q = q[i], sigma = sigma)
  
  x <- problem$x
  y <- problem$y
  signals <- problem$nonzero
  
  fit <- owl(x,
             y,
             penalty = "slope", 
             lambda = "gaussian", 
             sigma = sigma,
             intercept = FALSE)
  
  selected_golem <- which(abs(coef(fit)) > 0)
  V <- length(setdiff(selected_golem, signals))
  R <- length(selected_golem)
  fdr[i] <- V/R
}

xyplot(fdr ~ q, type = "b", ylab = "FDR",
       panel = function(...) {
         panel.refline(h = 0.2)
         panel.xyplot(...)
       })

Control of false discovery rate using SLOPE.

Group SLOPE

The Group SLOPE penalty (Brzyski et al. 2018) works very much like the regular SLOPE penalty but on the group level instead of on a per-observation basis.

Much like the group lasso, Group SLOPE ensures that the coefficients for the features of a given group are either all zero or all non-zero.

References

Brzyski, Damian, Alexej Gossmann, Weijie Su, and Małgorzata Bogdan. 2018. “Group SLOPE – Adaptive Selection of Groups of Predictors.” Journal of the American Statistical Association, January, 1–15. https://doi.org/10/gfrd93.
